item.title: Project Euler 77: Prime Summations
item.description: Problem Statement It is possible to write 10 as the sum of primes in exactly 5 different ways: \begin{equation*} \begin{split} 10 &= 7+3 \\ &= 5+5 \\ &= 5+3+2 \\ &= 2+2+1 \\ &= 3+3+2+2 \\ &= 2+2+2+2+2 \end{split} \end{equation*} How many ways can \(N\) be written as the sum of primes? My Algorithm Please see my solution to Project Euler 31, as we use the same dynamic programming techniques.

item.title: Project Euler 31: Coin Sums
